title: Unseen disabilities
body: Their is no section for MRI but I was referred by opathamology. I rang not once but three times as I'm very allergic. This was to avoid an incomplete test or a reaction. I arrived in time wasn't asked to go through safety form by support assistant. I had to point out that I had problems with constrast and that usually a special one had to be ordered . Would it be possible to check. I was spoken to quite rudely as if it was too much trouble and as if I had learning difficulties, I was wearing the sunflower lanyard which is intended to promote respect if you have a dissibility that's not immediately evident so informed that she would get the radiographer. 45 mins later one arrived clearly pulled out of her lunch. No body had recorded that I had reacted previously and there was a risk. She gave me the information leaflet . It said in large letters do not use with patients with severe asthma! No alternative was available, no dr, no crash cart, no epipens. I had the scan without the contrast but was then informed by my consultant I should have had the contrast! This is an issue the trust needs to address . Allergies are serious and appropriate measures need to be taken if a patient flags this. I have flagged this with PALs but nothing has been done. It's hampered my treatment and made me feel I'm wasting time.

readBy.name: Plymouth University Urgent and Emergency Care Bsc (2020)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Excellent Practice
body: All of the staff I was in contact with was very kind, respectful, compassionate and competent. Sadly, I had to move into another area leaving behind the excellent doctor that I had.

title: Fantastic care received for my husband yesterday
body: I would just like to say the care my husband received yesterday was 5 star, not sure who the dr was who he spoke to but you prescribed him some treatment and it was at the pharmacy imminently to collect, heâ€™s been poorly for a week and now picking up thanks to you.

title: Excellent service
body: I want for a flu jab today, 14.1.20. Service really well organised and excellent. Very helpful staff at the entrance, at the hand cleaning point   where to go along the corridor to ge the jab. Clear and straightforward injection. Brilliant service as I always experience  at Leiston Surgery. Many thanks. Jack Broom

title: Well managed
body: I only went for a flu injection and was in and out in a matter of a few minutes. The receptionist and both nurses were pleasant and friendly and I was unconcerned about any infection.

title: Great experience
body:
I have just had surgery on my ear and just wanted to say thank you to all the staff on mottistone suite and all the ent and theatre staff that looked after me so well and also kept reassuring me as I was nervous about my surgery and nothing was to much trouble.
Please once again pass on my thanks to all the staff

title: Amazing staff
body: I canâ€™t remember all the names because of all the painkillers but I had my baby at 11ish 13/11/2020. I was in from around 9ish hours before on ward 64. All the midwives, nurses, doctors and the students were the friendliest and warmest people I have met. Not once did I feel uneasy or scared. I was even rush down to theatre for a minor procedure and didnâ€™t feel scared. I donâ€™t think I have met a single person in my 36 hour stay that wasnâ€™t lovely. I wish I could remember names to name all individually too. A big thank you to the kind wonderful staff and soon to be staff that looked after me and my baby. You made it all a lot easier and smoothly for me and my family

title: Wonderful service
body: I wish to thank all the staff, nurses, doctors, ambulance staff, who cared for me on my recent emergency visit to the hospital. They were very busy but the treatment I received was excellent. Everyone was very caring and considerate and I cannot praise you enough for the help and treatment you gave me. We are so fortunate to have in our town a wonderful hospital with caring and dedicated staff who are there to help us when we need them. Thank you all.

readBy.name: East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust

title: Flu jab today
body: I wanted to highlight the efficiency & professionalism of my flu jab today. Covid makes Healthcare more difficult, but my local surgery are excellent & today was equally impressive. We often dwell on negative things, I wanted to highlight a great experience today. Jason Oakley

title: Wonderful practice
body: Had a lot of medical problems over the years and white house surgery could not of been more helpful there team are friendly so helpful as they are to my mum and dad especially with my repeat prescription so I don't have to worry been with them over 25 years

title: Give wrong information yesterday and terribleâ€¦
body: I was told to yesterday to call today(Saturday am) to the surgery so I did, was greeted gentlemen to say that the surgery was closed and call back on Monday. I explained that I was informed yesterday to call in today as I work Mon-Fri and that I said this to your colleague yesterday but he said I had got it wrong and if I wasn't happy to leave a review on the web site , ...REALLY ?? Is that the way to treat people, I think not ! But unfortunately if no one is held to task/made accountable  things will stay the same and no doubt deteriorate.

title: Absolutely brilliant practice all round!
body: What a fantastic practice this is! From start to finish. My husband, 4 children and myself are all registered and so use the practice regularly between us! All staff are always cheery and helpful and Dr's and Nurses always listen and take their time to think through your problem and different routes of treatment. I have never left feeling dissatisfied or concerned that I wasn't really listened to. I really could not wish to be with a better care provider- Thank You Woodbury!!

title: Thank you everyone
body: Would like to SAY a big  thank you to all the staff , Every one was so kind,  I felt totally safe in these difficult times ,  and so grateful my opp was funded by the Nhs, I could not have received any better treatment if I had paid private .  Keep safe everyone .

title: Great Practice
body:
Brilliant service offered to patients from the doctors and the staff who work there. My family and I are immensely grateful for the
care we receive.
Thank you so much.

title: Very poor quality of service
body: I have been having problems in injecting insulin, I tried couple of time and my local pharmacy has all tried to get this problem sorted, but the reception staff have no interest in getting this problem solved

title: One of the Very Best Hospitals.  A++++
body:
Excellent.  Both myself and all the other patients I met were very impressed with the care and treatment we received in the AMU and Redlynch Ward.  The nurses, doctors and other NHS staff all worked very hard.  I wish to add that the food we were given was also the best I have been in a hospital and a huge improvemen on my previous visit 25 years ago 
The Catering Department can be very proud of themselves.

title: O65 Flu Clinic
body:
I attended Corfe Hills School for my first flu vaccination & was incredibly impressed with the whole operation. Well staffed, efficient & friendly & reassuring staff.
Thank you

title: Understanding Staff
body: I came to this Centre for Biopsy and was extremely nervous.Staff were fantastic and made me feel at ease.

title: Efficient and friendly team
body: I've registered here recently and i can honestly say this is the best surgery i've been too, all the staff are so friendly and hardworking especially in this pandemic i've received all the care i needed and i'm so grateful for that.

title: Very informative
body: Having a bone scan was a very good experience in the department. Staff excellent, very reassuring, explained the whole procedure, I am extremely claustrophobic but was treated so well I got through it no problem, extremely good department well deserved praise.

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent service throughout !
body:
I had a hernia operation on the 23rd October 2020 at Kingston Hospital, in the morning.
Regretfully, because of my nervousness, I was unable to register all the names of the staff who were so good to me that day. However, I must register my satisfaction at their dedication towards me. Starting with the Consultant who was going to perform the procedure. He was friendly, professional and reassuring. Followed by the anaesthetist    who was just as friendly and efficient and even put on my tight socks for me. Throughout my wait several members of staff performed their duties with professionalism and care. At Theatre No. 4, I was met by, again friendly and professional nurses, who put me at ease by talking to me in Portuguese and cracking jokes amongst themselves. I was feeling very vulnerable and apprehensive, but their attitude helped me immensely. Please let them know how fantastic they are ! To be honest the whole team are worth the highest of praise. From the nurses who attended to me at Recovery and their smiles, the catering lady who brought me tea and an excellent chicken and leak pie ! And finally, the porter who wheeled to the Exit because I was still a bit unsteady and worried about getting lost in the labyrinthine corridors. In these though times because of the pandemic they are all courageous 
people who are a credit to our NHS. Today the 15th November I am recovering fine with no infections and the pains have abated somewhat.

title: Incredible service
body: I was admitted to A and E on the morning of 1 Nov 2020 with severe head pain.  Firstly, the ambulance crew arrived within 5 minutes of our call and were fantastic, so calm and reassuring. I was immediately taken to a quiet side room as my pain was so intense and was seen very quickly and intravenous pain relief and a rehydrating drip set up. One of the duty doctors came to explain I would need a CT scan which was arranged quickly.  Another doctor then came to say a lumbar puncture was needed to eliminate a brain bleed and advised me to have this done in case the CT scan had missed a small bleed.  She was very clear and reassured me this was the best option.  I was then transferred to AMU where the procedure was carried out that evening.  I was so impressed by the calm and kindness of everyone who dealt with me on a busy day, with the additional pressures of COVID restrictions to deal with.  A and E staff, I cannot thank you enough.  I had first class treatment.  Thank you all most sincerely.

readBy.name: Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital NHS Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Wonderful service and staff
body: I attended this hospital on Friday 13th November and even allowing for the date I was apprehensive about having a cystoscopy procedure done. From the moment I walked into the hospital the staff were very attentive and professional and everyone put my mind at ease. The procedure itself was not painful as I did not feel a thing. Also, none of the possible side effects have taken place so far and therefore the treatment I received was second to none, especially considering the present concerns regarding COVID-19. Please thank all the staff who attended to me in the Treatment Centre.

title: Great practice
body: Fantastic service, very friendly and puts you at ease. Very well organised with all the covid restrictions making you feel very safe when you attend. Keep all all the hard work!!

title: Fantastic and Covid safe services
body:
Every member of staff was helpful, kind and cheerful in spite of the fact they all had to wear masks all day and the facility was very warm. 
I felt extremely safe and well looked after. 
The longest wait I had was ten minutes and for my first appointment I was actually called in early.

title: First class service
body: Just completed 5yrs  care at this department. My consultant was knowledgeable, skilled and caring. All the team were fantastic. I feel so lucky to have been so successfully treated and thank everyone for there help in literally saving my life.

title: Superb treatment
body:
I recently completed a course of treatment at the Widnes hospital for cataract operations, both of which were successful. 
From my initial referral in January, I had my first operation in February. Unfortunately due to Covid 19 I was unable to proceed with the second operation  until October.
I wish to express my gratitude and appreciation for the level of care and service provided by everyone. From reception to the medical team they were caring, helpful and supportive.
I initially felt a little apprehensive but was assured by the professionalism and commitment of the staff.
The level of Covid 19 restrictions put in place were exceptional and I had no reason to be fearful as regards to health and safety procedures and standards.
I feel that the clinic fully deserves it's high star rating and I would not hesitate in recommending Spa Medica to others.
Many thanks to all.

title: Outstanding courtesy and treatment
body:
I went for an endoscopy on Monday 9th November From reception to being prepared for examination onto the discussion before the examination then the procedure itâ€™s self to recovery and discharge.
The staff at all levels treated me with respect answered all my questions and I have nothing but praise for them all thank you
Keep up the excellent work in harder than normal times

title: Flu jab - great practice
body: Had an appointment booked for Saturday afternoon. All the queue was nicely socially distanced, outside the doctors. We were called in, by name, in groups of four, and met inside by a really polite member of staff. Hand sanitizer was there for us to use. Another member of the team was there to direct us to our nurse, who was ready for us. Exit was via the side door. All in all a very positive and safe experience, and lovely welcoming staff and nurses. Thank you to the team, for being so warm, welcoming and organised

title: Difficult to get to speak to Doctor
body:
Long wait to speak to reception, when you do the receptionist is not always helpful, Iâ€™ve rang twice and my request dismissed without taking my name. 
I have recently used online consultation and decided this is the best way to speak to a professional I am now undergoing investigations.
I am not comfortable with discussing my medical issues and reception making decisions.

title: Incredible staff
body:
Every contact I have had with the practice - from reception staff to clinicians - has always been professional and caring. 
This month the practice nurse kindly squeezed my little boy in for his flu vac when the appointment system went wrong and the reception team have gone above and beyond to sort out prescription issues for me.
The surgery - like all NHS services - are facing a long and challenging winter as has never been seen before. I want to add my sincere thanks for their incredible hard work in looking after my family amongst their thousands of patients. I feel that our health is in safe and knowledgeable hands.
Stay safe, stay well and know that all of your hard work is appreciated beyond words.

title: Good clinic with a strong/ professional/ caringâ€¦
body: The pre op staff should emphasize more on how both a near or far lens would benefit the patientâ€™s life, let them thoroughly understand the situation so they can make the right decision. I went with distance lens as that was the norm, but not knowing the norm wasnâ€™t for me as 60+% of my life is near distance (pc, fix cars, diy) so now I have to wear glasses 60+% of the times. I would have much preferred it the other way.

title: Excellent prescription management team
body:
I have had to phone the prescription team for help twice recently and on both occasions the member of staff answering the dedicated prescription phone line has been extremely helpful and efficient but also courteous and kind.  I find that all the front line staff at 
Compass House answer the phone in a friendly manner and all have a â€˜can doâ€™ manner which makes all the difference.

title: Very unhelpful
body: I went in with an injured leg and couldnâ€™t put any weight on my leg so had to hop in. The best way I can describe the triage nurse is hugely unhelpful and lazy. Someone who must have been moved from other departments for her lack of empathy and lack of effort. She revelled in what little power she had without thinking of the people she was being paid to care for. Making me hop around without offering assistance. Sending me back to hop to the seating area because although there was no one at the desk she hadnâ€™t called me up. She could see I was struggling to move around. She did the same thing again when I was sent to her for crutches. No care or attention. A disgrace to the NHS

title: Friendly and professional
body: As a registered patient, I have always received outstanding care from everyone from receptionists to clinicians.

title: Great practice
body: I had my 2nd cataract op in october. The staff were all very nice and treated me very well. Any questions I asked were answered thoughtfully and throughly.

title: Can't thank the hospital enough
body: The neurology team at Southmead saved my life and prevented my being brain damaged by performing emergency  surgery after a subdural haemotoma. I cannot adequately express my gratitude to them. The care and kindness I received from the skilled doctors, nurses and other professionals could not have been bettered. Thank you, all of you, you were wonderful.

readBy.name: Plymouth University Urgent and Emergency Care Bsc (2020)

title: A wonderful, caring, efficient group of people
body:
I moved to Winchester recently and joined the Friarsgate Practice.  Unfortunately I ran into a bout of ill health, but fortunately under the care of Friarsgate.  Every person with whom I have been in contact from admin, secretarial, appointments, pharmacy, phlebotomist, nursing staff and doctors have provide an exemplary, efficient, helpful and caring service.  The associated Community Nurse service has been just as good.  It reads bizarrely to say that I am glad I have been ill under the care of Friarsgate but I dread to think of the situation if I had been with previous practices.  It is so lovely to phone Friarsgate and get a caring helpful response rather than the begrudging answers I had been used to elsewhere.
While I speak very highly of the Friarsgate staff, I would also acknowledge that the practice leadership and management must also be of a high quality.
Would I recommend Friarsgate.. Like a shot!

title: Worst GB
body:
I have been 9 years in England but this is the worst GB I've ever been with. So hard to book an appointment and if you get booked then they will make sure after a week. 
I remember doctors start asking questions about working full or part time like if I need to apply for a job. The way he speaks with attitude, he didn't help me at all not even prescription. 
I moved out of the area but this will be in my head this is how bad he was. 
Totally not useful, I don't recommend it to anyone.

title: Doctor I saw needs a training
body: I was referred to see upper limb consultant shoulder surgeon from pain management clinic and this doctor said, "we do not specialised in cervical ribs, we specialised in bones". This doctor really needs training. Orthopaedic clinic specialised in cervical ribs and bones. The most funny was for me when he said" your shoulder absolutely fine and I will discharge you back to GP".He refused to refer me back to vascular clinic.  I think I need to take this case further. The doctor was unprofessional and inexperienced. Just wasted my time. The doctor does not have enough knowledge to  answer  simple questions. This doctor need to work under supervision still, his not capable to work on his own. Really disappointed with the service I received. Just wondering, how this doctor could pass an interview to get this job??? I supposed to see consultant according to my referral request and instead got inexperienced doctor with minimum knowledge. Why patients have to waste their time to see this kind of doctors ????

author: Patent123
title: Sick child
body: Completely useless... My 4 years old son start complaining about stomachache pain... crying, of course temperature went up... as normally happen with stomach sickness, happened to me many times ... no other symptoms... called reception to book appointment for my son... been refused because of child temperature and told to call 119... what a useless service...

author: LiszyW
title: Wrong prescription given
body: I have been on the same contraceptive pill for some time, during Covid I have phoned through for repeat prescriptions and they have sent them to my local pharmacy to collect. So far so good until last week when someone decided to prescribe an unbranded version of the pill I take which has previously caused me to have spotting etc. Perhaps trying to provide a cheaper product, not checking patients records and above all no consultation with patient. Went to collect prescription and had to reject as was the wrong item. Disappointing!

author: pavojf39
title: Bad receptionist
body:
I feel the reception staff are rude, have no people skills, bad telephone manners, and this has led to a dysfunctional service, reception staff think they are the GP`s - they pick and choose who they are nice too,  
I had to change GP surgery due to feeling unwelcome and always becoming frustrated when having to contact the surgery.  
My father who is still a patient has a number of health issues and is waiting to have a lung removed - no compassion from the staff and keeping him waiting for his medication on a regular basis, he has a pacemaker fitted and in recovery from throat cancer,COPD and diabetes .  
In my opinion the reception staff have a training need or they are just employing anyone - I would not recommend Peel Hall surgery

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: spukemonkey
title: Stopping my medication
body:
I rang 111 and was booked into the urgent treatment centre but once I arrived due to my notes and history I was sent to A&E thinking they would help. Once I had done my urine test, blood an infection was detected but they needed a blood test (which I refused earlier due to the fact it will come back normal and they will fob me off).  
I was feeling nauseous all night and after the blood test I couldn't hold back the sickness so the doctor prescribed me anti sickness medication which I didn't get until 5 mins before I left the department due to the doctor forgetting (too little too late).  
I am also having difficulty with my mental state with the pain I have been in a long time and this extra pain don't help...I feel this was ignored.  
I have also expressed this with my GP and that also was ignored. Since this whole experience both from pilgrim and my GP I am now considering de-registering from GP and never bothering with any NHS treatment again, I have a long term condition which I am stopping all medication for and this current UTI (which they want to test for cancer) I will be cancelling the appointment for the specialist.  
They have made me feel alone so I will be be alone (no treatment of any nhs service) even if it kills me

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Tomasina
title: Assessment for a wheelchair
body: My Mother, who is now 84, had a massive Stroke 5 years ago. Prior to the Stoke my Mother was proud, fiercely independent and in good health for her age. She is an amazing individual, worked all her life, a great Mum and wife. Sadly the Stoke took away her ability to ever walk again and brought on vascular dementia. My Mother's current wheelchair was becoming uncomfortable and she was able to spend shorter periods of time in this chair therefore was spending more time in bed. A referral for a new wheelchair was made by myself and her care home in September 2019, I was told at this time that there was a 9 month waiting list, just for a referral, which would take it up to summer 2020 however this was delayed again and so I called in September 2020 to be told due to coronaviras, there was a further delay of three months. However I recently received a call from Occupational Therapist who had been to see Mum, and who was extremely helpful, explaining that they had recommended the care home provide a static chair, also highlighted the need for Mum to receive an assessment for new wheelchair and gave several reasons why. I then called the SMART centre to chase up the assessment, I was told Mum is near the top of the list and it has been agreed a video assessment would take place soon. Today however I received a phone call from SMART centre to inform me that there is a backlog of 18 months? I had to check they had the correct person which was confirmed. I asked to speak with someone else, they said there was no point but would 'put a note on' for a specialist, I explained what my experience was, that I was told only recently that Mum would receive her long-awaited assessment and that this figure of 18 months seems to have come from nowhere. They replied it certainly had not, I felt I was getting nowhere so I called the occupational therapist and left a voicemail. My family are already going through so much, my Dad is also elderly and we have only managed to see Mum once since lockdown, we think of her constantly and want to know she is as comfortable as possible. Mum currently does not have a wheelchair which meets her needs, and no static chair though I understand this is not an issue for NHS, however "whoever is responsible for what" does not mean anything to my Mother, all that matters is she is being let down. I am sure the OT will call me, I was impressed by their professionalism and compassion however I feel the need to do something right now as I am not prepared to allow this to go on much longer and certainly not 18 months. It makes me so so sad and frustrated that someone who deserves so much more is given so little.

author: Coughy McWheezy
title: COVID-19 testing
body:
I recently attended for a Covid test at the Emirates arena. I had felt a bit under the weather for a few days and then developed a dry, wheezy cough and sore throat, so thought it would be safer to get tested. I was a bit upset and anxious when I arrived as I didn't know what to expect and was worried that if I did have the virus I may have passed it on to other people without knowing. The staff there put me at ease right away and the place was very efficiently run. I was given a swab and asked to pull into a space, where a very kind worker talked me through how to use it. He really helped make the process much less worrying and made me feel so much better. My test was done in less than 15 minutes and I got my results that evening. Thankfully they were negative!  
Just wanted to let the team at the Emirates Arena know what a fantastic job they're doing, making a scary experience much less worrying. You're the best!

author: M-2000
title: Felt guilty asking for help
body:
I now feel confident enough to tell this story.  
I attended CAMHS for a few years until around 2018. I struggled a lot with depression, suicidal thoughts and anxiety. I am a very shy girl. The nurse I was speaking to would get very impatient with me. I once told them I was feeling suicidal at that moment, and they said that neither of us could leave until I say I'm fine. I felt that the notes were written to make it look like there was progress.  
There was also a psychiatrist that was completely rude and I felt was mocking me. Their words still hurt me to this day. I was to have an appointment to discuss medication as I was just going down hill. I noticed that the manners and body language used didn't seem caring or professional at all. I talked about my suicide attempts, which were happening around 2-3 times a week. At my description of one of my attempts, the staff member was extremely dismissive and rolled their eyes. Then told me that I must not have wanted to do it if I ended up phoning someone for help, which I felt was hinting that I was doing it for attention. About the medication, said that no medication will stop you from doing what I had done, referring to the suicide attempt that had not been taken seriously. I already knew anti-depressants didn't work that way, which I kept saying.  
A while later, I had attempted again and ended up in the A&E, when the nurse was reading my notes from CAMHS, it had said I had been seeking attention, this is the last thing I wanted people to think about me. I had started to believe these things and felt guilty asking for help.  
A while after turning 18, I started with adult mental health services. There is such a huge difference to the level of care provided here. They were fantastic with me and I actually felt listened to.  
From noticing this big difference and have experienced what I did at CAMHS, I am now studying to become a nurse. I just hope that the staff from CAMHS realise why they are here and re-evaluate their work ethics. You should never treat someone that way, especially people who feel vulnerable.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Spiridoula
title: My experience in assessment unit
body:
I was taken by ambulance to Ayr Hospital. The paramedics were exemplary. When I arrived I was seen straight away by nurses who were also exemplary. Up until now all of these caring professionals were kind, helpful and reassuring.  
I was taken to A and E and was told I would be moved when a bed became available. There were no beds available so I stayed in A and E all night long. I was there for over 12 hours. It was a dreadful night and I didn't sleep at all so was exhausted by morning. This was not the fault of any member of staff there, just circumstance. A doctor saw me at 2am. They confirmed, as had everyone throughout the entire process, that there was an anomaly in my ECGs that indicated a possible previous/recent heart attack. The doctor said that I needed to see a cardiologist who would both scan the heart and perform a stress test. A cardiologist would also assess any relevant medication. They listened to my symptoms, not just the current ones, but everything that had led me to this point.Early in the morning I was moved to Assessment, and stayed there without any communication until around 12.30 when a doctor came in to the cubicle. At around 11 I had asked a passing nurse for some information. I was shown some notes explaining that I was to be referred as an out patient for a heart scan and a treadmill test and that I would receive medication, including something to reduce cholesterol before being discharged.When the doctor came in, it was clear they had not read my notes, knew nothing about my case, was not aware that I had been there all night as he thought I had just arrived. Wouldn't let me speak, told me they weren't interested in family history as regards heart disease, or anything else. Didn't know my cholesterol levels when I managed to ask. I felt this doctor was rude, aggressive, belligerent and dismissive. This made me feel guilty for being there. This staff member was in the cubicle for less than a minute, during which time, contradicted everything their colleagues had said. I asked about the heart scan that had been mentioned. They replied that it was them who would make that decision, and that they were not interested in anyone else's opinion. I was told that there was nothing wrong with me, to get dressed and go. I left feeling emotionally assaulted, very worried, confused and extremely upset. Given that at least 5 medical professionals had told me that there was a risk that I had already had a heart attack, after everything I'd been through, not just at the hospital but with my health generally I felt borderline suicidal when I left the unit.I asked the name of the doctor and was reluctantly given a name. I enquired whether this person was a cardiologist and was told that they were not. Whoever this person was, the experience completely destroyed me. Even if they were indeed correct and every single one of their colleagues wrong, the manner of this staff member is possibly the worst I've ever encountered. I felt that they dismissed me, and the opinion of colleagues and other hospital staff, as being lesser.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland
St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Scottie2020
title: My father's care
body:
My father attended Jubilee Cardiology day unit for angiogram. Due to extent of damage, he was admitted late on Friday to 2East. He was then moved on the Saturday to 2C to a room with no shower facility and a frosted window. There appears to have been multiple discussions with Clinicians regarding heart damage and intervention. Father had many Doctors visit him discuss their views and then another doctor would have differing views, each time being advised he would be discussed at MDT next day. On Monday am he was given a gown and mentally prepared himself for the lab, however then another Doctor advised they were still unsure of best action and a Senior needed to review him. Further 2 Surgeons then visited the following day to rule out a bypass due to risks. Therefore Dad was prepared again on the Wednesday morning for the lab and sat another full day waiting until confirmed by 7pm he would not be taken, the impact of the growth of anxiety and then the disappointment is detrimental to overall health.  
Meanwhile, throughout this time, no visitors are allowed, therefore Dad has sat confined to room for 7 days now, with nil purposeful activity being offered to improve mental & physical wellbeing. I have listened on the telephone to my Father on a daily basis deteriorating in mood, motivation, function and skills. Given how overwhelmed he has felt, the increasing anxiety regarding the news and the indecisiveness regarding the intervention, it is extremely disappointing that Father has waited so long for intervention, and that no alternative social supports can be offered to him, not even PT securing some exercises to his bedroom wall to give him some purpose whilst he waits within the room.  
I am deeply saddened to witness the deterioration in Fathers mental wellbeing due to unnecessary delays, poor communication amongst staff and also with family, not to mention the Covid risks waiting such length of time in hospital for a procedure. Hospital staff need to appreciate the vast impact on patients currently within hospitals with no family support and no-one to advocate when medical information is overwhelming.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Successful
title: Recovery
body:
I was supported for 5 months by the Orion unit in Bullwell Nottingham to get better. Worries about Coronavirus got the better of me, searching all the time. Reach day centre was closed and lock down had got to me. I managed to make friends with a lady named Shona. We often went out with Jenny and various other people staff members.  
Things that could have been improved was on when I returned from a trial run stay over and came back asked if had a shower to be told by me I have only just got back. Lovely birthday party. Did not like when staff were falling out and going to take me out and then being told by another staff member you can not take her out she is on my observation. Since being home things have gone from strength to strength, extra support from reach care and attended day centre full dayâ€™s 4 days a week. And once or twice a week have ICATT visits to see how I am getting on. I am showering and washing my own hair I am doing small shops on my own and weekly shops with reach care staff on a Thursday my day off reach. And washing laundry. Try to cook own tea and make my own breakfast and pack up. I catch up with church on youtube for service and zoom chat afterwards. I keep in contact with friends. I am learning to get used to signing still and taking my own tablets. Helps to have a small read about autism spectrum which I did not know I had with the learning disability. I am always trying my best and keeping in contact with friends and family via phone calls and facebook messenger and e-mails. Really appreciated all the help I had and support especially from Keri HCA. And Jenny and Simon and Megan and dawn, assistant manager I think named Beverly. Thank you to you all for helping me through my recovery means a lot.Hope this gives a good brief summary of how I am getting on and makes everyone as happy as we are. Hope you are all well? Many thanks, kind regards. X

author: LVV
title: Wonderful care
body:
Our daughter has had the misfortune of having 3 admissions to the QMC in recent months  
. However on each admission she has received the most incredible care and we are eternally grateful. We would like to say a big thank you to all the doctors, nurses and support staff at 111, EMAS, ED, PICU, CAU, D33 and Dr Bhatts respiratory team, for the knowledge, skills, expertise, professionalism, kindness and compassion you have shown my daughter and also for the facilities and support you have provided to us parents.We feel very privileged to have access to such a service and to have such dedicated people caring for our little girl. Thank you!!

author: Pa Pa
title: The care and attention I received lately
body:
I attended the A&E unit at Foresterhill lately because my left calf had swollen and was red and hard. It was Friday night and the leg had been painful in the early evening but at my age I thought nothing about it until I examined my leg later in the evening. On seeing my leg my wife was quite alarmed and had me drive with her to A&E.  
At A&E I had to wait a little while till I was seen and assessed by a nurse. She advised me that it could take some time to be seen. I informed her that because of the Covid 19 situation my wife was not admitted to the hospital and that she was in the car outside. The nurse suggested that if she took a blood sample for examination then I could take my wife home and return for further treatment. This was done.  
On return I was examined several times and advised to stay in hospital overnight. I spent a quiet night in a single room. In the morning it was found that a scan could not be carried out .It was decided to teach me how to inject myself then come back to hospital for more treatment the following Tuesday. This was done and the following Tuesday I returned for a scan and further examinations.  
In conclusion, the nursing and medical staff were very attentive, professional, dedicated, and friendly. I cannot remember their names but I will never forget them.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Friendly Practice
body:
Every care was taken too protect all patients against COVID-19 . 
The staff where firm but friendly on any advice given out.

title: Excellent care
body: I contacted the surgery at 8am on Friday morning with an urgent problem. I received a call back from the GP before 9, delivered a sample at 10, had a call back with the results at 2pm and had a GP appointment at 3pm. I was give a prescription there and then, and was referred to Kingsmill for tests. I received the appointment for those on Monday and had a scan on Tuesday. Well done Collingham - excellent service again

title: Prompt service - exceeded expectation
body: Great service - very prompt response.  I'd arranged for a blood test at Vicarage Lane on 11th Nov, and by the 12th I received a text that my bloods had been reviewed and a prescription written by one of the doctors.  As I had a couple of questions, I requested a consultation on the DrIQ app and I received a call from a doctor almost straight away!  Knowledgable and great service despite the huge pressures faced by the NHS.  Keep up the good work.

title: dreadful practice
body: i did a review not long ago and was told things would improve i am sorry to say they have not when you ring to speak to receptionist you can wait up to 45 minutes to speak to some one i think this is dreadful. come on herne hill group practice wake up this the year  2020 you need to get your act together

title: No complaints
body: I have no complaints at  all the guys at the practice have tried their all to help us and they must have so much pressure on the them

title: Bad practice
body:
I have repeat prescription for two medicine: 
Salbutamol ( I received)
56  /30 mg  lansoprazole and they canceled my prescription.
I update my adress online but they send my out from this practice without medicine.
I can't update my new address because of lockdown .
No medicine in lockdown

author: decemberyb83
title: Very helpful at Crosshouse Ward 3E
body:
Everyone very helpful and nice  
No complaints whatsoever

author: firezj83
title: Exemplary Treatment at Crosshouse Ward 3E
body: The way that I have been treated during stay has been exemplary. The staff are very friendly. I have loved being in the ward.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: centaurusgy37
title: Couldn't fault the care at Crosshouse Ward 3E
body:
Couldn't fault the care  
The biggest problem is the staff are overworked

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

title: Efficient and friendly service
body:
Flu jab on sat morning
Whisked through the queu
Friendly assistants
Efficient injection
Overall impressed with how easy it all was

author: Ruby Tuesday
title: My husband's stroke
body:
Over a weekend back in June my husband complained of a light but constant headache and a slight numbness to the right side of his tongue. On the Monday morning he said his tongue still felt funny (no drooping of mouth and could move his tongue evenly to left & right side of cheek) but also said his eyesight did not feel quite right. We immediately called 999.  
On arrival of the ambulance they found his blood pressure very high. My husband was relatively fit and not overweight and was in good health and did not suffer from any underlying problems other than light asthma. He had not seen a doctor or had his blood pressure taken for about 8 years. He was rushed to hospital and over 4 days had MRI scans, CT scans, ultrasound and lumbar puncture taken but nothing abnormal was found. The first consultant he saw thought he had suffered from a TIA but the two subsequent consultants decided that it hadnâ€™t been a TIA and that his symptoms were a result of high blood pressure. He was released after 3 days. He was released with a blood pressure monitor to wear for 48 hours then when that was returned, a heart monitor for 24 hours. I believe neither of these recordings showed anything untoward. He attended our own medical surgery where he spoke to another doctor. He again complained of the odd feeling in his tongue but was told this could just be down to nerve damage. How I wish we had insisted he be readmitted!  
A week later my husband suffered from a major stroke. He was rushed to hospital and medicated. Unfortunately swelling occurred at the site of stroke, causing pressure build up which we were told would be fatal without intervention. My husband was rushed to a neurological unit at QUEH where he underwent a craniotomy to the left side of his head. The large piece of skull removed from the left hand side of his head was placed in his abdomen for safe keeping. He survived. More than two months later he was allowed home where therapy continued. A further three months later he had further surgery to replace the piece of skull onto his head. He has now been allowed home.  
Due to the stroke my husband now suffers from aphasia. He struggles with nouns and names particularly, he does not know the alphabet and cannot read or write. He does not always understand questions and often struggles to find words when asked direct questions. He has slight weakness in his right side and a lack of dexterity in his right hand. He has forgotten how to work tools and electrical items.  
There is no doubt that my husband received and continues to receive, on the most part, outstanding care during a time complicated by the Covid 19 situation but there are a few occasions where I feel we have been let down.  
1. The very first consultant being overruled as to first diagnosis of a TIA.  
2. The doctor at our local medical practice dismissing tongue paralysis as nerve damage.  
3. After my husbands craniotomy no one phoned to let us know he was out of surgery or that it had gone ok. I phoned the ward at 2am to ask if he was out of theatre to discover that surgery finished over 3 hours earlier. A day and a half after surgery, I still hadnâ€™t been contacted by a medical practitioner & it took me to ask specifically for a doctor, registrar or consultant to phone me before that contact and update was made.  
4. The same occurred whilst my husband recuperated in hospital. I had to request a doctor/consultant contact me with an update as to his condition. Nursing staff were fabulous but could only provide me with limited information and because of my husbands aphasia he could not remember and/or physically tell me anything the doctors had discussed with him.  
5. When my husband had his skull replaced, first a nurse and then a doctor phoned me on the date of his admission as my husband was unable to answer their questions and they were unsure if he understood all that he was being told.  
My husband contacted me on his return to the ward after surgery. It is very disappointing that to date no medical practitioner has contacted me with an update as to how the surgery went. My husband was unable to ask them questions due to his slowness of speech and inability to find the right words of the subject matter and he is unable to tell me what information the consultant and registrars told him.  
If we were not dealing with Covid restrictions I would have frequently been visiting my husband and present for ward rounds where I could have listened and asked questions on his behalf.  
6. A decision was made that my husband could go home at approximately 5pm on a Sunday. We stay approximately 1 hour from the hospital and it was after 6pm by arrived to pick him up. The main doors to neurology were locked and unattended. On phoning the ward they directed me to a back door and a nurse brought my husband down. The lighting outside was very poor and taking someone who has had major surgery down and up pavements and across roads in poorly lit conditions not ideal. The nurse could hardly read his discharge notes and medication.  
Both operations have gone well and my husband is working very hard to improve in all the areas in which he has been affected. He has had outstanding care from medical staff, nurses and therapists during very difficult circumstances this year. Where we feel greatly let down is on points one and two and then mostly the lack of communication, updates, information & advice from medical staff for points 3 -5.  
Point 6 just felt rushed and inappropriate & could/should have been better done.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: sw13
title: Very helpful and supportive
body: In for day surgery 10 Nov 20 . Nurses very helpful and supportive - even though they were very busy. Everything very efficient. Very happy about care

title: Fantastic service during unprecedented times.
body: Couldnâ€™t be happier with the care I have received over the past few months from the practice. Attentive and considerate admin and reception staff are always on hand to sort an appointment to suit you. Fantastic experience with all GPs I have seen. The transition to phone appointments was smooth and works great for those who donâ€™t need to visit the practice.

author: karall
title: Made me feel cared for
body:
Saw my GP who quickly referred me to gynaecology. He also gave me encouragement for the procedures I was to go through.  
Had examination at gynaecology department then had hysteroscopy followed, not long after, by hysterectomy.  
My GP and the staff at Borders General Hospital were all absolute angels. They made me feel cared for.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

title: Efficient and responsive
body: I had a couple of queries on joining the practice; the first was dealt with via e-consult and generated a reply the next working day. The second was by phone - which was answered within less than two minutes, and required a call back from another staff member. That came within 10 minutes and my query was dealt with comprehensively- and an appointment for routine tests made, there and then. Excellent service - couldnâ€™t ask for more.

author: Patient CH
title: Minor operation
body: I recently attended the Dermatology Department on 2 occasions. The first was to have a mole assessed by Dr Sinclair after a referral was made by my GP Nurse Practitioner. Dr Sinclair was extremely friendly and professional, she assessed my mole and agreed that it should be removed as a precaution. Dr Sinclair explained the process, listened to me and understood my anxieties about the procedure and my upcoming wedding. With this information she made arrangements for the procedure to take place afterwards. On my second attendance, my minor op was carried out by Kirsty and Gillian who both put me at ease with their caring, friendly and professional approach. The procedure was explained to me before, and during (which took no time at all) and I was given aftercare advice. Everyone I encountered was extremely knowledgeable and and answered all my questions. My appointments were taken on time (maybe even a few minutes earlier than scheduled! ) I can't thank the dermatology dept enough for such a great patient experience.

readBy.name: MASScot- Melanoma Action and Support Scotland

title: Receptionist was so rude in the blood reception
body: I have just witnessed an elderly gentleman enter the blood service reception, he was hard of hearing and wanted to ask about parking. The receptionist was on the phone, she literally blasted at him that she wAs on the phone. He was clearly struggling to hear and the way she dealt with him was disgraceful. I appreciate everyone is under pressure at the moment but you would never get away with that in the private sector.

author: Amazing staff
title: My experience at gartnavel
body: 10/11/20 I had surgery on my hand under mr littles care & staff, From entering ward 4a to theatre to leaving my care & staff couldnâ€™t have been any better, staff nurse Linda, auxiliaries, Alan the porter, to theatre staff, my theatre nurse was Ann, lovely lady very caring& attentive, anesthetist was amazing too, all actual theatre staff & especially mr /dr little a huge thank you for all your help & care 10/10

author: Sobriety
title: Dependency/ongoing recovery support
body:
I realised I had a problem with alcohol few years back and reached out for help as it was affecting my life in many ways negatively, I was referred to Huntingdon Inclusion (now CGL)  
From day 1 onwards I have had ongoing support, ranging from 1: 1 support, structured groups, peer support, therapeutic groups, out of hours support, I have been through many challenges, vulnerable situations, crisis, relapses, I have had and am still receiving excellent support, I have been to detox/ rehab earlier in the year my keyworker and the team, made this happen for me from preparation stage all the way through.  
I however since relapsed end of June this year, once again fully supported by Cgl every step of the way, I went for a detox and am receiving after care with Cgl face to face and via zoom. The Cambs recovery service is also fantastic with many zoom groups from recovery cafe, media power hour, wellbeing, quiz and so much, Cgl and Cambs recovery service users are listened to 100 percent and we have a service user forum weekly or us to say whatâ€™s good, whatâ€™s not and suggestions of new groups/activities weâ€™d like to see, we do see results and positive outcomes.  
I cannot thank Cgl enough for all they do for me and others, once upon a time I couldnâ€™t see any light. I am fully valued and treated with respect and dignity, everyone is freindly and approachable. A lot of the workers have lived experiences which I believe is a true asset as they have been where we are and can relate and that in itself is inspirational and encouraging that recovery is possible ðŸ™‚

title: Fantastic diagnosis and care
body:
I have recently been diagnosed with trigeminal-neuralgia which affects 12 in 100,000 people. Despite the NHS being really stretch with covid I got diagnosed within 1 day, at my first appointment. Some people wait years to be diagnosed. This practice has made things so much better for me and supported me in a way I know a lot of other people haven't been in other places.

Every doctor I have spoken to; the one who diagnosed me, the one who helped me with my medication after I had bad side effects and the one who reviewed the new medication has been amazing. For every doctor to know about my condition and how to treat it means their communication is fantastic. They are empathetic and have done as much as they can to help me and manage my pain. 

Any appointments I have had before this diagnosis has also been excellent. This surgery is fantastic and provides excellent care.

author: deltawz96
title: Unhelpful treatment
body:
In my opinion Telford STARS seems to be run by people who do not understand the science of drug metabolism as they have been found to frequently be unaware of specific metabolites of opiates and other drugs leading to many false negative tests.  
On top of this, I have found them to be unhelpful and abrasive, and unwilling to help me because I don't fit their preconceptions of what someone battling addiction should be, calling me lazy and unmotivated for being unable to stick to their reduction plan, while the service offered me no support.  
I have found it impossible to get any sort of actual medical help such as drugs to aid in the process of getting clean. This is especially true if I do produce a negative test, and as mentioned before, due to their limited scientific knowledge most tests come back negative. From my experience I would not recommend this service, overall I have found it demoralising and a contrived system of jumping through multiple hoops just to be turned away with nothing.

author: Debseydoo
title: Unable to pass urine
body: Got told I needed a catheter and then got told I didn't   need one I sent home with antibiotics

author: Frank but not too Frank
title: The Care I receive
body:
I have been going for Intravenous Imuglobulin treatment on a regular basis for many years and every time I arrive for my appointment the staff treat me like a family member. They are so genuinely warm and friendly and their care and attention to their trade is second to none.  
I feel very safe every time I attend and it's a testament to their commitment to providing the best service they can. Thank for everything you do.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Marigh44
title: Gallbladder surgery
body: I was having gallbladder surgery and I felt a bit anxious, but when I arrived at the day surgery the staff were so nice, while waiting for my operation the nurses were talking and making conversation which was really nice, after my surgery the nurses were really good getting me something to drink and something to eat, I was asked if I wanted dinner as I was advised by the surgeon to stay overnight, I was given my own side room, the nurses were always checking in to see if I wanted anything or if I needed pain relief, I had a good overnight stay and in the morning I was given breakfast and was allowed to go home, the staff were amazing I was able to ask them anything and I'm so glad my surgery was done here the surgeon was amazing and the staff are all so lovely

author: Worried2728
title: Miscarriage
body:
I miscarried about 3 weeks ago at 6 weeks pregnant on a Saturday night. Due to the bleeding becoming heavy I had to go into maternity assessment at 10pm and was seen quickly by a midwife and a doctor. Thankfully the bleeding subsided so I could go home and arrangements were made to be seen by EPAS on the Monday.  
The staff at EPAS could not have been any nicer and sympathetic towards my partner an I. From the radiographer to the midwives to the nursing assistants everyone was lovely. After finding out that we had miscarried our baby after both scans (one to confirm that everything had passed) we were led to a private room to sit which allowed us time to grieve in a private area away from everyone else. I can't think the staff at EPAS enough who seen me so quickly during these uncertain times.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

title: every nurse should be like this
body: The nurse took a blood sample this morning:efficient of course ,but beyond the call of duty she made my day.She was very friendly and caring..It was a pleasure to meet her.This is not just her job,it is her vocation.Well done Peel Hall Medical Practice for having her on your team.Clone her immediately.

author: Oats
title: Hip replacement  clinic
body: I must thank Mr Alipour he has magic hands, saw him today for my check up, it's been a Long journey from mid January until now, I still have a bit to go, I can't thank him enough and his team thanks again for looking after me on the morning on the day of my surgery in January cos I was real nervous, nice lady in recovery was really nice I big thank you to her too

title: Absolute disgrace
body: This surgery has deteriorated so much in recent years. Having been a patient for over 25 years, I am so disappointed in the service, or lack thereof. One particular doctor is fantastic and has been my GP for years, I'm sure the other GPs are lovely too, but that's assuming you can get an appointment. Having called every morning at 8am for  the last 9 days, I have been unable to get through to book an appointment. This morning I called over 100 times and could still not get through. They need to change the appointment system because patients are suffering whilst waiting to see a doctor. This place should be avoided at all costs until they do. From a very dissatisfied patient.

author: Irish72
title: A credit to the hospital
body:
From start of admission to discharge the attention and approach by the staff was amazing. I had an emergency admission from my GP surgery possible PE. Thankfully it was pleurisy and nothing to serious.  
From the minute of admission I was assessed immediately informed of every step taken and reassured all the way. I feel safe and looked after and knew I was in great hands. The consultant was amazing. I have forgotten his name but when he heard I was a nurse in Glasgow he was asking my opinion on the service and my words to him were that I thought the unit was amazing. I had 5 hours watching as there really isn't much to do when waiting to go for scans and await blood tests. Scans were done very quickly and bloods taken immediately on admission.  
I did all my nurse placements in Ayr hospital watching how the staff conducted themselves and how proficient and professional they were in the unit that day is a credit to the hospital.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: AKAJB
title: Urgent referral waiting times
body: Been referred to DGRI, urgent referral via fantastic GP. Waited 4 weeks before hearing anything to find appointment in another 4 weeks? 8 weeks for urgent referral with some really awful symptoms. Phoned by secretary to be told this is due to Covid? I do not feel my health ( or ill health), is in safe hands! ! !

author: Emmrd63
title: IMCA Service - Litigation Friend
body:
Cal,  
  
Thank you for this report â€“ itâ€™s great. Honestly itâ€™s fantastic.

author: Marpm83
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Virtual Diwali celebration
body: Thank you so much to the Well being team [at St Luke's Hospice] for organising the virtual Diwali celebration chat yesterday.   It was wonderful to see everyone and the decorations made it feel like Diwali: brilliant job. The session was enjoyable and a good opportunity to meet people I haven't seen since March 2020.

author: Marpm83
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Virtual Diwali celebration organised at short notice
body: It was really great taking part in the virtual Diwali celebration. May I say that you and the guys [from the Well Being team at St Luke's Hospice] did really well under such short notice in organising it.   It was also interesting to meet people and perhaps take this opportunity to enlarge our group in the future for other events.

author: Shaun Gee
title: Brilliant service
body:
Had to contact surgery at Poole Road Medical Centre a couple of times over lockdown and so impressed with the responses from the receptionists, nurses, doctors and staff.  
E-consult really good for non urgent issues. GREAT service in these challenging times. Thank you All.

author: Marpm83
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Virtual Diwali celebration lead by St Luke's Hospice
body: I thoroughly enjoyed the [virtual Diwali] session, especially because I haven't seen some people since March, so it has been 8 months.   It was really good to catch up and made me feel very happy.   I would definitely join in on any other virtual sessions which are available and recommend them to others.

author: Service user9876
title: Treated with kindness
body: I have received great care from this hospital during a procedure yesterday. All of the staff were lovely. I was treated with kindness and respect at all times.

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

author: LC79
title: Nurse experience and compassion - second to none
body:
I was diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis in July 2019 and took the opportunity of being offered an Alcohol Related Long Term Health Conditions Nurse, Kirsty.  
Kirsty has been an incredible asset to my health problems; we would meet weekly and discuss my health conditions and concerns. Any questions I have she answers me with reassurance and explanations.  
As covid-19 came into action, we have continuously maintained contact via telephone. On one occasion when I was concerned about my symptoms, Kirsty visited me with full PPE to check my vitals and observe my physical condition.  
As my diagnosis has recently undergone scrutiny, Kirsty has always been there to offer support and guidance, even during times when we haven't had appointments booked. Kirsty has also liaised on my behalf with my Hepatology Consultant.  
I feel very confident with Kirsty, and feel like I can be up front and honest without any judgement from her. In my experience, this is a key attribute to a good working relationship and without her I believe my lifestyle changes would have been a far greater challenge to achieve.  
I have worked with numerous health professionals in my life. I value Kirsty as an integral part of helping me with my health problems and (hopefully, someday) recovery; her experience and compassion are by far second to none.

author: mattie mae
title: laser treatment by optician
body: I was treated by receptionists nurses and opticians a few weeks ago at Inverclyde out patient hospital I was received and treated with much kindness and understanding and the laser treatment was for me a miracle giving me back one eye weakened by posterior capsule opacification. I want to thank everyone in the waiting room downstairs and also all in the department of opthalmalogy and especially to the opticien Abbey who performed the treatment. I was thrilled on seeing the sky totally when leaving the hospital that day Thank you!

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: beenz
title: lack of concern
body:
Last week I called my gp practice and complained about chest pains, shortness of breath and palpitations.  
I was told I'd get a call back which I did five and a half hours later which I find unacceptable, just to think a doctor has had lunch before getting back to a patient who incidentally had already been in hospital with a serious heart condition (I'm on my second pacemaker) as I felt it necessary to phone an ambulance.

title: Incompetent
body: My wife was taken to New Cross for a suspected stroke. Spent two hours trying to find out her condition and was transferred SEVEN times between departments back and forth. Tried ringing the acute stroke unit 10 times and was cut off every time. This is a shambles of a service.

author: Doc R
title: District Nurses
body: For several weeks the district nurses in Shreborne have been attending my wife for pressure sores and ulcers once or twice a week. We have been impressed by their punctuality, professionalism and pleasant demeanour. They make an amateur' carer's job a lot simpler! ! !

readBy.name: Dorset HealthCare University NHS Foundation Trust

author: Jezabelle
title: Broken femur
body:
Broke femur August this year and was admitted to ward 15 and operated on the next day. Staff could not have been better and was transferred to ward 14 where staff were equally good even though they were under a lot of pressure from what I consider difficult patients. Managed to leave hospital after four days, the last night being sleepless because of patient causing disturbance. Staff showed remarkable patience and am most grateful to them for their care and to the doctors who performed operation.  
Making good progress after physiotherapy,

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: Chonzie
title: Minor op
body: I had a first class experience when I had a biopsy done at Stirling hospital.   I was cared for by Angela and Pamela who were very reassuring whilst carrying out my procedure. As professional nurses I canâ€™t praise them high enough

author: Raku
title: My Care gets more attention than I do!
body:
This week I was a day surgery patient at the RD&E and I witnessed nurses, doctors, and theatre staff frustrated and exasperated by the new online My Care system. This had a great impact on my personal experience which resulted in me feeling more like an inconvenience than a patient. Every person I met, including the consultant, seemed more focused on completing the demands of My Care than engaging and communicating with me as a patient.  
Medical staff congregated in corridors around monitors which created access pinch points. These pinch points made wheelchair movement difficult and COVID-19 social distancing impossible.  
Normal nursing care and empathy was noticeably absent. In fact very little attention was given to me. So much so that during my seven hour stay I was not even offered a glass of water. My Care was clearly needing much more attention than me. I was not given any post operative advice, verbally or in writing upon discharge.  
I have experienced other surgeries in my life and this was the first time I ever felt unsafe, uncared for and â€˜processedâ€™ in a hospital ward.  
I am not a Luddite and recognise that change and systems have to be updated for the benefit of all. However â€˜patient careâ€™ needs to be maintained as a priority ahead of â€˜My Careâ€™. At this moment in time patients already have additional COVID-19 anxieties. They do not need to be concerned that they are not getting the full attention of the medical teams.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust
Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust (2)

author: Person centred
title: Lack of communication
body:
I contacted the surgery on a Friday in November to renew my sick note. I waited all day until 17:00 then called again . I wasn't on any list and the receptionist was unsure if I would receive my note via text as before or the Dr would call.  
An hour later, I received a text to say contact the surgery on the following Monday.  
On the Monday, I called the surgery 0800. Requested to speak to a Gp to have my sick note reviewed. After no text or call by 17:00 I contacted the Gp again and find I had been issued with a further note and needed to collect this now from the surgery .  
It would have been nice to know this today what I needed to do.

author: Miss J 85
title: Pregnancy Loss
body:
Whilst going through my first experience of pregnancy and suffering a pregnancy loss, what I feel most is disappointment in the level of support that is available around miscarriage. From my very first contact with my midwife I was advised that official contact would take place after 8 weeks as this is the timeframe in which women most commonly suffer a miscarriage. A time when women may need the most support of all is when they are left alone to experience a loss that is traumatic not only physically but emotionally and mentally, with little communication or information.  
Following some bleeding at 9 weeks I was offered an early scan at the Early Pregnancy Assessment Unit. At this scan I was informed that my pregnancy had likely stopped growing but I would need to come back in 7 days to confirm. The midwife who spoke with me on this day was very professional however 3 key elements were missing for me - Care, Compassion and Communication. I left feeling very confused and felt the whole experience was very cold and impersonal. I therefore contacted my allocated midwife the following day who only upon receipt of my call checked the system and realised my situation. Again I found this very impersonal and if not for a phone call from me would I have had any contact from her? In fact, from this date I have never again heard from my midwife. I feel like I was only a number, and not a human being who was going through a traumatic experience. I've never received any results from blood tests, which I requested and the notes on my Maternity Notes App are sparse. These may have not given me any answers but I felt it was my right to know the outcome.  
Following a second scan a week later, I was again left confused as it appeared that the pregnancy that had stopped growing at 6 weeks had infact grown in the 7 days since my last appointment meaning that I had to wait another 7 days for confirmation of miscarriage. During this scan, I would like to highlight that the midwife I dealt with was very empathetic, supportive and interested in my wellbeing and this made the world of difference to my experience and how I was feeling. She was very informative and if not for her input my whole experience would have been a negative one.  
The day after my second scan I began to experience severe cramping and bleeding and contacted the Early Pregnancy Assessment Unit for advice. During this conversation I was advised to take paracetamol and have a hot bath. I was also asked to take a pregnancy test the day prior to my next appointment and if this was negative to cancel my appointment. I was horrified by this and whilst the information was again delivered professionally, I found it cruel to ask a woman suffering a miscarriage to take a pregnancy test and to end care at that point should a pregnancy test be negative, taking into consideration the fact that nothing had been officially confirmed to me prior to this point and the only closure I would get would be from a further appointment.  
After, I guess what you could call lucky, a further pregnancy test was positive, I attended my final scan appointment to which I was met by the same midwife again who was able to confirm my miscarriage and showed me the care, compassion and support that had been missing from most of my pregnancy experience. The only saving grace from my whole experience was the contact I had with this midwife and her ability to shine light at the end of a very dark tunnel.  
On the whole, I do not feel that I was appropriately supported throughout my pregnancy experience and feel this issue needs to be highlighted and a change of practice implemented so that women like myself are not made to feel pushed aside when their pregnancy is no longer viable. A miscarriage is a very lonely and harrowing experience which is only made worse with a lack of communication, information and support.  
Whilst I appreciate the impact that Covid-19 has had on front line services and the pressures that comes with this, I don't feel this is an excuse for a lack of care, compassion and communication. These simple steps are all it took for me to feel better informed and more supported and the fact that it was not common practice in my experience makes me sad, especially for those women who may be going through what I have gone through. I can only hope that by sharing my experience, that someone else has a more positive experience that I did.

author: Snail
title: Problems with my only foot
body: Came to A& E from Bury as I was having problems with my only foot as I lost the other due to circulation problems and Oldham has a vascular unit. They saw me 5 times, it wasn't a circulatory problem and I'd just like to thank them!

author: Coppercurls
title: The lack of communication to home
body:
My husband's stay in D7 Dumfries and Galloway royal infirmary and the lack of communication to home  
My husband has been in D7 Dumfries and Galloway for the last six weeks and although I am satisfied with his medical care I am very annoyed at the lack of communication.  
He went there as an emergency and does not have a phone with him and has to rely on using their one and only phone on the ward to phone home or for me to phone and ask to speak to him and he tells me he can't get this phone sometimes waiting up to four hours to be able to call his wife.  
More often he just doesn't get it at all after having been told by staff that he would get. His wife has repeatedly tried to phone but is cut off or unable to get any answer and is often told that there is no phone but they will get it for him! after which does not happen. He is 80yrs old and I don't think this is the correct way to treat him or his wife. A complaint was made but appears to have been useless.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland
